Magyar

 

 

Expat Medical was the first medical provider in Hungary concentrating on the expat community here. It still may be the best, although not the best known anymore. It works on a different scheme, compared to the other private and public clinics, hospitals.
Description
After 20 years in operation we might still be the best for those expats in Budapest and surrounding who value a service that may not be available from other private clinics.
What do we offer, they don't?
1/ Perfect communication in English, German, French, Hungarian, Italian, (a somewhat slower version in Russian.)
2/ Our services are based on a very personal relationship between your family and D
r. Tibor Timar, the family doctor, pediatrician and ent specialist, founder of Expat Medical. Having one doctor you can turn to for any medical problem gives you a much better founded feeling of security. During his 20 years with patients of all nationalities, Dr. Timar has seen Americans, Germans, Chinese, French, Japanese, and others surprised about Hungarian habits, but also Germans wanting to have a British vaccination schedule to be continued or Russians needing help with the American International School Budapest to be informed about the content of the shots they had received in Japan.
This is a truely international medical provider.
3/ Have you heard that in the beginning of the 20th century doctors used to make house visits even in the US? We still do that!
We do it, not the subcontractor who subcontracts a Hungarian-only-speaking, tired and nervous doctor who has to take the job because he is so badly paid for his work in a state clinic. Who does not understand why you want to know what the problem with you is, not just take the tablets prescribed.
4/ There are many huge problems in medicine in Hungary. Let's talk about one that is not unique to our country, although it may be more significant here than in "more lucky" places. How does the patient know that he needs the service he is buying. Well, often he doesn't. Many times the patient thinks he is sold a lot more procedures, medicines, even surgical operations than necessary, and unfortunately this may happen to be true.
Imagine you have invested a huge amount of money into a medical facility. Are you going to leave the door to the laboratory closed, or are you going to find out that numerous patients have to have blood taken and analyzed? When you find a number slightly above or under the normal range, are you going to say that this is not significant, or are you going to order a control exam. In the latter case the patient will see how consciencious you are, and - just as a welcome side effect - your investment will also return a little earlier.
5/ So you have your laboratory and radiology. Patients want a long list of specialists on the wall, so they will be happy to have someone for each organ they have. So the owner opens more rooms and looks for more doctors to work for him. As he will not have a patient to be offered to a specialist but once or twice a week, he will not employ this specialist. He will call in a doctor to see a patient. This means that the doctor will spend at least 90 minutes for a 30 minute visit in the clinic, but will be paid - as it happens - about a third, or often much less, of what the patient pays. (I was told by a very reliable experienced colleague, a pulmonologist, that she was paid 5.000 (five) HUF for the hour when the patient was charged 40 000 (forty) for 30 minutes. This happenned in the fanciest private clinic in Budapest, about two years ago. The doctor is not available for them anymore, but with the current income level of doctors in Hungarian hospitals there is always someone forced to take an offer like this. Needless to say, this may not be the most experinced specialist in the respective field.)
So we prefer to find an experienced specialist for our patients and ask him/her where he/she can be consulted under civilized conditions. If he prefers to see the patient in our clinic, we will not benefit from the difference of the fees paid and passed on, but from the patient's having received a qualified service and being satisfied.
